content: One thing I should throw out there: we may be able to get funding for professional translation this year.
We have in the past few years had professional help for shaping/processing the survey results, which was definitely a win.

I did a quick Google search and didn't find anything that appealing. I asked on Twitter and got a few suggestions:

  • https://crowdin.com/
  • https://www.thgfluently.com/
  • https://www.deepl.com (ML-only)
crowdin looks the most promising so far. It does machine translations that are then checked by humans. Seems to be used in open source as well.
Looks like their pricing is on a monthly basis so they operate in a more long term approach. Not sure how that translates to what we need
It's more aligned for app translation so there might be some friction there.
(I do wonder if we should have a larger conversation about translation services with the foundation - such services would be useful in many other places)

@rylev as per crowdin faq, it's completely free for open-source project.
More information can be found on their Open-source project setup request form
Yes, we'll have to see if a survey would fall into that category since we're not translating Rust itself :wink:
I've sent an request to crowdin. Let's see what they say...
Hmm we've already been "approved" - perhaps we can play around and try it out
https://crowdin.com/project/rust2021survey
@rylev I'm confused why to use a third-party translation service when we operate one ourselves?
@Florian Gilcher can you explain what you mean by a translation service we operate ourselves? I wasn't aware of one (other than the volunteer network we have - which I wouldn't call a "service").
We operate https://pontoon.rust-lang.org/ for the website and potentially other things.
This is news to me!
Is this linked to from anywhere ? I personally didn't know it existed, it looks cool
Yea I'm assuming this has been advertised around before, but maybe it's time to do another round of advertising for it. This is cool!
I'll put this on the list for investigation. Thank you @Florian Gilcher for bring this to my attention!
https://github.com/rust-lang/www.rust-lang.org/blob/master/TRANSLATIONS.md
LMK when you need help, I'm the operator.

So, my .2 cents on the matter:

  • Translating the survey questions is not the problem. I think that we (as in "we volunteers") can do it ourselves starting from last year's questionnaire + the delta of additional work. Though we ended up observing that survey questions in different languages were misaligned. The idea of adding some machinery to automate the survey generation aired (I did some research) but due to lack of time nothing was really investigated/implemented. @Florian Gilcher I think Pontoon could be tested for this part.

  • The tricky part is translating answers. Fixed form answers (yes/no, multiple choice) are out of the way with some copy&paste. Free-form answers otoh might end up being only partially machine translatable; the human reviewer would end up re-doing the work because a machine lacks context of what we're talking about, about any lingo, short forms, acronyms, references to people, facts, etc. For this task Pontoon is imo not suitable unless we can have a workflow to easily import && export from Pontoon.

Also for answers, we're dealing with potentially private data. We don't want to expose people's answers to literally everyone (otherwise we'd need to update our privacy policy). So we're still going to need a different policy for translating free form answers. I do wonder if machine translation first + human review is the right way to go. We're not dealing with carefully crafted marketing messages or app instructions that need to be perfect. We just want to ensure that those doing analysis and don't speak a particular language get the right idea.

Are you referring to PID (personal identifiable data) in free form answers? Ideally the privacy issue could be solved by stripping away one or two columns (IIRC contact email) from the Google Forms CSV export before handing answers to the translation people.

Having to review all answers in all languages for PID content before starting the translation work looks to me a lot of work.
Now, just thinking out loud, but I wonder if it could make sense could warning people about that (such as a disclaimer "hey dont put PID in answers, just use the contact field at the end of the survey if you want")
I mean, the workflow question with all tools already poses itself on the starting side: we have multiple google forms, we also need to export/import/sync.
@Florian Gilcher would you be able to set up a Rust 2021 Survey project in pontoon?
@rylev sure, is there a GH repository?
No there is not. I’m not sure even what format it should be in.

Stripping the email would only half work: it is supposed to be used by translators to contact people that had especially interesting remarks or questions in their native language, I think it’s even marked as the reason for email gathering

@Florian Gilcher you asked if there's a GitHub repo for the survey - there's not as much of the survey design in the past has been done in Google docs. I can work with someone to set up a repo, but would for should that repo take - or more specifically - what form should the survey questions document take?
@Florian Gilcher ^^ping
@rylev sorry. feel free to check: https://github.com/rust-lang/www.rust-lang.org/tree/master/locales

The format is called fluent. In this repos, only en-US is the lead translation. Pontoon indexes that and when a translation team signs of on a translation, pontoon does a commit like this: https://github.com/rust-lang/www.rust-lang.org/commit/82f5e58c18451dd6d924a26201d74e0508636c5d (attributing the author in the process)
